messageBody:
On Wed, 21 Feb 2001, Bob Krygowski wrote:

> Does anyone know if you can step through your code while running JUnit
> tests? I have been using JBuilder 4 and have only successfully been able to
> hit break points in the main method (which just ends up taking you to
> underlying JUnit code). In debugging I would like to be able to step
> through the individual tests and step into the actual class that is being
> tested to see what is going on.
>
> Any thoughts?

I do this all the time. The trick is to ensure your tests are thread
safe. Typically when I have trouble with something in the debugger,
it's because I've molested a visible swing component from my main test
thread instead of the swing event thread.

I've collected a number of methods to make this easier.

On my AllTests.java file I have:

/**
* Safely call doClick() on the specified JButton.
* @param button The button to doClick().
*/
public static void safeDoClick(final JButton button) {
try {
SwingUtilities.invokeAndWait(
new Runnable() {
/**
* Main processing method for the AllTests object
*/
public void run() {
button.doClick();
}
}
);
}
catch (Exception ex) {
ex.printStackTrace();
}
}

I use this within tests like so:

// foo.setWatched( buttonOne ); // not thread safe, dummy!
AllTests.safeDoClick( buttonOne );
